Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Protoflight Design and Validation of Molten Regolith Electrolysis Facility For Lunar In-Situ Resource Utilization
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project will be to advance space industrialization, exploration and colonization. The Moon has mineral deposits in its soil, and extraction is difficult. The proposed project will advance the analysis of the potential to extract breathable oxygen, metallurgical grade metals, and semiconductor quality silicon. This analysis extends the understanding of ultra-efficient processes for refining materials, particularly toward advanced operations in space.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to advance the translation of molten regolith electrolysis to refine lunar soil. The proposed project will: determine the operating conditions allowing uninterruptible electrolysis, develop preliminary designs of a molten regolith electrolysis facility, and conduct computer models of a system to refine lunar regolith in the lunar environment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lunar Resources is developing molten regolith electrolysis (MRE) for the extraction of metals and oxygen from lunar regolith (soil) on the Moon. MRE is a high-temperature electrolytic process in which the naturally high-oxide lunar regolith is liquefied and by the action of electric current is dissociated to electrowin liquid metal as a product and oxygen as a by-product. MRE needs ONLY power, oxides, and gravity to extract oxygen and metals from regolith on the Moon and as such is a highly advantegous technology for economic lunar resource extraction.

Our SBIR Phase I effort was highly successful and has produced a robust and implementable plan to construct a full-scale MRE system during the Phase II effort. The Phase I effort saw the laboratory testing of the MRE electrochemical process which demonstrated the generation of oxygen and metal on lunar regolith simulant. Then an MRE extractor cell anwas developed based on this process utilizing COMSOL Multiphysics modeling and SolidWorks CAD creating a preliminary MRE system design. Preliminary design simulations were then performed and demonstrated that the MRE system is capable of exceeding 5 year lifetime and commercial output requirements. The resulting effort has laid the foundation for a follow-on Phase II effort to:  a) develop a prototype MRE system designed in Phase I; and b) test the system in the laboratory and vacuum envirorment. The team believes the Phase I project progress to date has led to the most consequential advancement of MRE technology to date and will result in an operating MRE system on the Moon.


Last Modified: 03/01/2021
Modified by: Donald R Sadoway

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Lunar Resources is developing molten regolith electrolysis (MRE) for the extraction of metals and oxygen from lunar regolith (soil) on the Moon. MRE is a high-temperature electrolytic process in which the naturally high-oxide lunar regolith is liquefied and by the action of electric current is dissociated to electrowin liquid metal as a product and oxygen as a by-product. MRE needs ONLY power, oxides, and gravity to extract oxygen and metals from regolith on the Moon and as such is a highly advantegous technology for economic lunar resource extraction. Our SBIR Phase I effort was highly successful and has produced a robust and implementable plan to construct a full-scale MRE system during the Phase II effort. The Phase I effort saw the laboratory testing of the MRE electrochemical process which demonstrated the generation of oxygen and metal on lunar regolith simulant. Then an MRE extractor cell anwas developed based on this process utilizing COMSOL Multiphysics modeling and SolidWorks CAD creating a preliminary MRE system design. Preliminary design simulations were then performed and demonstrated that the MRE system is capable of exceeding 5 year lifetime and commercial output requirements. The resulting effort has laid the foundation for a follow-on Phase II effort to: a) develop a prototype MRE system designed in Phase I; and b) test the system in the laboratory and vacuum envirorment. The team believes the Phase I project progress to date has led to the most consequential advancement of MRE technology to date and will result in an operating MRE system on the Moon.
